QuoteText: so you dont think much of cops or firefighters? what about those of us who drive to work every day? not true after BCT. do you mean other than LEO, security, and middle management experance for most sgt and above? i had electronics training in the army, i was also a paratrooper, i had no other training in my curren job field (repairing medical equipment), and i can say with out question you do learn transferabul skills. a lot of the guys i served with choose to join, not there was nothing better they could do. the reasons were diffrent for everyone, one guy was tired of having every thing handed to him, anouther wanted to get a collage education payed for, with few lones, another had a kid on the way, and needed the medical coverage, or the one who wanted to get out of town as soon as he could. from what i experanced in the 82nd abn div the dumb ones were the exceptions. so there are no beight guys working in a manufacturing or assembly environment?
ResponseText: I respect anyone who is making their contribution to society. That doesn't mean I personally admire all choices on how to accomplish same. I know cops, truck drivers, etc., but that's not something I would have chosen as a career. I've been out of it for some time, but other than lifer officers and draftees who had their educations interrupted I never knew anyone with a volunteer military service record who was hired for a middle management position with a major corporation, though I'd think defense and other government associated businesses would be obvious exceptions. Most lacked the formal credential of a degree. I'm sure there are bright people who worked in manufacturing, may still be in what manufacturing is left. Unless things have changed, it was a very rare occasion when someone was promoted from the floor into management as again, they lacked the credentials. Again, each person makes choices. That doesn't mean their choices are suitable for or admired by everyone.

QuoteText: things have changed a lot, i knew an E-6 who walked out of the army into a management position. it is no problem to get a degree when in the army, they have the courses on post, or correspondence courses. i knew a combat engineer who was working on there third batchlers degree.
ResponseText: My entire family has long done a stint in the military. My father always believed that all males should pull at least four years in the military after HS to serve thier country. He changed his view on that when Bush got elected . My daughter just passed her two year recall option , Thank God after a six year stint with the army. I can tell you things certainly have changed in the military . My daughter is a pharmacist , now though no thanks to the military as a matter of fact her college class's were dropped twice due to the military never bothering to pay the bills. Not to mention a lot of these kids were told they could go to Iraq and come right back to where they were in thier studies when they left and are finding out thats a joke. setting them back years. It took her eight years to get the degree, because the Army kept interfering. Two of my brothers were in thier 12 th years , one with the Army and one with the Air force when they were forced out in cost cutting measures. in the 90's . yep that can be blamed on Clinton, But Bush is actually worse , he believes in cost cutting when they are no longer useful the way big business does. besides the fact he believes in starting a war before the troops are properly eguipped for thier own saftey. So all of Washington has shown they care little for the lives of soldiers. They are now running the military like a business and downsizing and cut backs are normal . They'd like to have my brothers back , now that they are at war as well as many others they forced out so they wouldn't have to pay retirements on them. Fat chance! My daughter does some volunteer time at a VA hospital along with my youngest son who's a Orthopedic Surgeon. Anybody who works in the VA system will tell you after they bust out of Walter Reed , forget it they are under staffed and under funded. Just a FYI so you don't get to thinking they value soldiers , lifes or well being. They don't its aparent to even old retired Marine SGT's like my father now days. Oh sure they want them after they are educated, they wanted both my sons after they got thier degrees , but thank God thier papa had wisened up and as much as he hated to say it , because the Marines were his life long pride and joy he advised both his grandsons , not to join. Just a FYI for you ,many life long military families see the lack of concern for the soldiers as proof they should not volunteer thier lives for men who don't place a value on them.

The most important thing is that they are held accountable for their actions and made an example of. The worst thing that could happen is that the military tries to bury it to protect the image of the uniform.

ResponseText: Sure, let me find some.... Ok here... Comparing Military and Civilian Rape Rates To place military rape rates in context, it is valuable to compare them with civilian rates. Comparisons of the crime rates of civilian and military populations during peacetime periods in 198692 reveal that contemporary peacetime rates of rape by American military personnel are actually lower (controlling for age and gender) than civilian rates. However, the data also indicate that peacetime military rape rates are diminished far less from civilian rates than are military rates for other violent offenses. This rape differential is also reflected in the World War II data: U.S. Army rape rates in Europe climbed to several times the U.S. civilian rates for that period, while military rates for other violent crimes were roughly equivalent to civilian rates. Thus, in both contexts studied, a rape differential exists: the ratio of military rape rates to civilian rape rates is substantially larger than the ratio of military rates to civilian rates for other violent crimes http://www.answers.com/topic/rape-by-military-personnel Other violent crimes violent crimes in general by today's vets who are out of the military... So, using the lowest of the lowball numbers -- 121 acts of mayhem out of 700,000 veterans spread over six years yields a rate of 17.28/100,000 veterans overall. But the New York Times numbers are misleading. This is because with that 121, we now learn that they included 22 cases of DUI, two cases of speeding, three situations which even the prosecution said were handgun accidents, and most incredibly, five cases where the accused was completely exonerated or their actions were determined (in a trial) to be in self-defense. So subtracting those out and the actual number that should be considered is 12.7/100,000. But that would be for a single year, and this needs to be spread out over six years. Mind you, that is also if you stick with the probably low 700,000 number of total Iraq/Afghanistan vets. Mind you we should also look at those stationed elsewhere. Let's try Japanoned! SOFA personnel comprise approximately 3.9 percent of the populating and committed about 1.7 percent of crimes (average, 1972-2001), or about half as much crime compared to the entire population of Okinawa. In the past ten years of data (1992-2001) SOFA personnel committed only 0.82 percent of crimes in Okinawa, or nearly five times less than the general population. (The Number of, 2001) http://www.dprkstudies.org/documents/asia015.html

CUNx, Comparisons of the crime rates of civilian and military populations during peacetime periods in 198692 reveal that contemporary peacetime rates of rape by American military personnel are actually lower (controlling for age and gender) than civilian rates. Do you really believe that using "data" that is anywhere from 16-22 years old gives a valid picture of the present reality? As I asked you previously, where's the beef in terms of current data?
